description:
Toxoplasma gondii COUG is a species of single-celled, obligate intracellular parasitic protozoan that belongs to the phylum Apicomplexa. It is the causative agent of the disease toxoplasmosis, which can infect a wide range of warm-blooded animals, including humans.

The COUG strain of T. gondii is a specific genotypic variant that was first isolated from a cougar (Puma concolor) in the United States. This strain is classified as a type II lineage, which is the most common type found in North America and Europe.

T. gondii COUG has a complex life cycle that involves both sexual and asexual stages. The sexual stage occurs exclusively in the intestines of felines, such as domestic cats, which serve as the definitive host. The asexual stage can infect a wide range of intermediate hosts, including humans, where the parasite can form tissue cysts and cause chronic infection.

The COUG strain of T. gondii is known to be genetically distinct from other common strains, which may result in differences in pathogenicity, host preference, and response to treatment. Understanding the specific characteristics of the COUG strain is important for epidemiological studies and the development of effective prevention and control strategies for toxoplasmosis.
